content:
Diagnosis:	Right breast adenoid cystic carcinoma, triple negative, BRCA1 positive

Management:	2023 Primary systemic chemotherapy - FEC-T
		Jan 2024 Right mastectomy and axillary clearance
		March 2024 Commenced carboplatin/gemcitabine

Histology:	Grade 3 adenoid cystic carcinoma, triple negative breast cancer
		pT4 N3 (12/15 nodes positive)
		Lymphovascular invasion present

Current Situation:	Progressive liver metastases on cycle 2 carboplatin/gemcitabine

I reviewed [redacted name] today who attended with her sister. Unfortunately, she has experienced significant clinical deterioration over the past three weeks. Her performance status has declined from 1 to 3, and she now requires assistance with most daily activities. She describes worsening right upper quadrant pain requiring increased doses of oxycodone, now taking 40mg every 4 hours. She has developed peripheral edema extending to her thighs, and her appetite has significantly decreased with 4kg weight loss over 2 weeks.

Her latest CT scan from 15/4/24 shows progressive disease with increase in size and number of liver metastases, largest lesion now measuring 8.2cm compared to 5.6cm six weeks ago. There is also new moderate volume ascites. Blood tests show deteriorating liver function with bilirubin 45, ALT 156, ALP 432.

Given the rapid progression through platinum-based chemotherapy and declining performance status, I have had a detailed discussion with [redacted name] about focusing on symptom control and quality of life. We have agreed to discontinue systemic anti-cancer therapy and I have made an urgent referral to the palliative care team. I have increased her oxycodone to 60mg every 4 hours and added metoclopramide for nausea.

I have arranged admission to [redacted name] Hospice for symptom management and support. The palliative care team will review her tomorrow, and I have provided my direct contact details to the hospice team. I have also referred to the ascitic drainage service for consideration of therapeutic paracentesis if clinically appropriate.

I have explained the situation carefully to [redacted name] and her sister, who understand that the focus of care is now on comfort and symptom control. They have my direct contact details if needed before the hospice admission is arranged.
